This is my desk.

There are many like it, but this one is mine. It’s pretty minimal, but it gets the job done.

Empathize

When I come to my desk for a new project, I start by putting on my empathy hat. To me, this is one of the most valuable parts of my design process. I like to envision a day in the life of my user and feel their pain points. I create personas that allow me to understand the different types of experiences that might bring a user to my product.

Research

I use resources such as customer support, sales teams, and user interviews to help build out my understanding of the user. If the client has been tracking any quantitative data, I also invite it to the party. This gets my bachelor’s in Quantitative Methods in Economics and Mathematics really excited.

Brainstorm/Prototype

I then invite my oldest friends, Pencil and Paper, over. We have a tea party (Earl Grey ftw), and after a few rounds, we get the basics together in a flow that can be shown to users and internal teams for feedback. I often invite Invision, one of Invision’s close relatives, or HTML/CSS into the mix depending on the vibe.

Polish

Before I take my work out, I normally dress it up with my new friend Sketch - but sometimes I reach out to my old friends Illustrator and Photoshop. I also like to bring my design to life using html, css, and javascript.

Test

During this time, I like to dress it up in a few different options and get user feedback. This process, called A/B testing, helps me figure out which version solves my user’s problems the best.

Ship

With that information, I polish it up and help my team ship it off.
